Vincenzo,

This is the procedure which I have used to interface FLUENT with
Cantera in linux.  It will
also probably work on any unix machine.

1) modify the "SRC=" line of file "Makefile" in the base directory of
the udf-library

SRC= ../../src/*.[chf] ../../src/makefile ../../src/*.cpp
../../src/*.hpp  ../../src/*.in

2) modify the "user modifiable" section of the the file "src/makefile"
of the udf-library

# location of non-fluent libraries (c++,fortran,c..)
LIB_DIR = /home/myname/cantera/lib/cantera
# c sources
SOURCES = my_udf.c 
# c++ sources
CXX_SOURCES = My_class.cpp my_funcs.cpp
# fortran sources
F_SOURCES = my.f
MY_INC = 
MY_LIB = -L$(LIB_DIR) -loneD -lzeroD -ltransport -lconverters -lcantera
-lrecipes \
 	-lcvode -lctlapack -lctmath -lctblas -lctcxx \
	-L/usr/lib/gcc-lib/i386-redhat-linux/2.96 -lg2c -lstdc++ -lgcc
-lm

CXX = g++
CXX_INCLUDES = -I /home/myname/cantera/include/cantera
CXX_FLAGS = -O2

F77 = g77
F_INCLUDES = 
F_FLAGS = -O2

3) This is probably not needed, but I have typically written a c-only
"my_udf.c" which contains
the functions which will be called directly by FLUENT.   The file
"my_funcs.cpp" contains the 
functions which are called by "my_udf.c" enclosed in an " extern "C" {
} " block.

4) If you use integrators, there could be a conflict(name clash)
between the cvode functions built 
into FLUENT and the cvode functions in Cantera.  

Hope this helps.
Dave

Dear prof Goodwin,
I examined your suggestions in the friday mail (about fluent 
simulations): thank you for that.
Now I have a further problem:
fluent accepts udf compiled only in c (libudf.so, created basically 
by the link of c functions); I tried then to link a c++ compiled 
function (with the extern C command inside you suggested) to c 
functions: fluent gave me an error because it can't recognize c++ 
functions even with "extern c" commands.
Do you have any idea about a possible solution?
Thank you so much again.

wonderful idea!
Bye. Vincenzo.
